Def.Name: Western Larch
Def.Description: Reaching 100' - 200' tall, with a trunk up to 5' in diameter. The crown is narrow conic; the main branches are level to upswept, with the side branches often drooping.
Def.Leaves: Needlelike, light green, 3/4" - 2" long, and very slender; they turn bright yellow in the fall, leaving the pale orange-brown shoots bare until the next spring.
Def.Twigs: The shoots are dimorphic; with growth divided into long shoots and bearing several buds, and short shoots with only a single bud.
Def.SeedConeOrFruit: Seed Cone: Ovoid-cylindric, 3/4" - 2" long, with 40 - 80 seed scales; each scale bearing an exserted bract. The cones are red when immature, turning brown and scales opening flat or reflexed to release the seeds when mature.
Def.Bark: Mature trees develop thick, grooved plate-like bark with cinnamon-couloured scales (similar to ponderosa pine bark).
Def.Range: Native to the mountains of western North America, and Canada. Grows well at about 1,500' - 8,000', and on the lower slopes of mountains.
Def.Remarks: Usually grows in mixed forests but can be found in pure groups after a severe wildfire. Very sensitive to frost damage.
